qas.question: The main jurors in Tom Robinson's trial were all which race?
How did Tom Robinson die in the novel?
At the time of the novel's setting, what punishment was often received by black males for percieved sexual contact with a white woman?
How many times was Tom shot?

context: Scholar Patrick Chura, who suggests Emmett Till was a model for Tom Robinson, enumerates the injustices endured by the fictional Tom that Till also faced. Chura notes the icon of the black rapist causing harm to the representation of the "mythologized vulnerable and sacred Southern womanhood". Any transgressions by black males that merely hinted at sexual contact with <a0_0>white<a0_0/> females during the time the novel was set often resulted in a punishment of <a2_0>death<a2_0/> for the accused. Tom Robinson's trial was juried by <a3_0>poor white farmers<a3_0/> who convicted him despite overwhelming evidence of his innocence, as more educated and moderate white townspeople supported the jury's decision. Furthermore, the victim of racial injustice in To Kill a Mockingbird was physically impaired, which made him unable to commit the act he was accused of, but also crippled him in other ways. Roslyn Siegel includes Tom Robinson as an example of the recurring motif among white Southern writers of the black man as "stupid, pathetic, defenseless, and dependent upon the fair dealing of the whites, rather than his own intelligence to save him". Although Tom is spared from being lynched, he is killed with excessive violence during an attempted escape from prison, <a1_0>shot <a4_0>seventeen<a4_0/> times<a1_0/>.
